1. Implement strict kitchen and production protocols: Restaurants and food manufacturers need to establish strict guidelines and protocols in their kitchens or production facilities to ensure that allergens are not present in their products. This can include separate equipment or utensils for preparing allergen-free meals or products, rigorous cleaning procedures, and proper training for all staff members.

2. Ingredient screening and sourcing: Restaurants and food manufacturers need to carefully screen all ingredients to identify any potential allergens. They should also work with suppliers to ensure that all ingredients are properly labeled, and that there is no contamination during shipping or storage.

3. Clear labeling: Clear and accurate labeling is crucial to help customers make informed decisions about what they eat. Restaurants and food manufacturers need to clearly label their dishes or products with any allergens they contain.

4. Testing: Restaurants and food manufacturers can use food testing services to verify that their products are free from allergens. This can include testing of ingredients, finished products, and surfaces in the kitchen or production facility.

5. Proper training for staff: All staff members need to be trained on the risks and dangers of allergens, and how to properly implement kitchen or production protocols. They should understand the importance of properly identifying and handling allergens, as well as how to respond in case of an allergic reaction.
